The backing on the final Something She record and a smash debut album produced by none other than talent finder and nurturer Becky herself. Ah ha! On the wings of angels, a goddess and three witches. Something Rotten Crassie and 0.2Z.! Becky jumps down, knocking herself and Cassie and some ge to the floor. Dottie and Roxie help Cassie. You can tell them that in the past fifteen minutes, the luster has fad Becky has alienated those who the Akergirls believed to b true partners. The attitude on display fills them with dr

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: Maybe we should come back. This doesn’t seem like the right time.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Night time is the right time. Bed ways is right ways. Tally ho!

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Not that we aren’t knocked on our ass flattered. We are.  53.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Then let the wild rumpus begin! Becky grabs an electric guitar and poorly shreds: “Garbag Dump” by Charles Manson.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Garbage dump, oh garbage dump Why are you called a garbage dump? You could feed the world with my garbage dump You could feed the world with my garbage dump

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Mari just left. We don’t need to be here right now. We can give ya your space. Like, this must not be super easy? Us showing up when shits all going down.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: ERRRRR. Wrong. I am the heart and soul of the band. I mean hello I named it after myself. I found those girlies and they were not the first and they will not be the last. I put Something She together from the ashes of failed junk bands, wanting to put one out there in my own name like god spewing mankind. That's ancient history and so are those ungrateful wenches who suckled at the teet of success that I placed upon their mouths. All I ask, before the four of us embark on this journey, is that you show me honesty and I'll do the same. That is the pillar of my music so enough with this jibber jabber and let’s rock. (back to the Manson song) That sums it up one big lump. Becky is mile a minute, machine gun rat a tat fast. It’s reading billboards from a roller coaster. She keeps strum her guitar, not well but not terribly either. The Akergir look on, dazed.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: What should we do?  24 25 54.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Well for starters go into that booth and wake those turds up and tell them that its blast off to the stars we go hit the fucking switch because the circus is leaving town and it ain’t comin’ back. There’s a silent pause where you can feel the Akergirls deciding if they should do this or turn tail and go home. Becky looks at them, aware of this indecision. She is sta sweaty, messed up, total maniac. Trying to catch her brea nearly ten years of her life torpedoed in the last half h It’s in her eyes: she looks beyond vulnerable and scared.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: (half afraid) We'll go get the rest of our gear.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: (like the Kool Aid Man)

dialogues.speaker: OH YEAH
dialogues.text: We follow the Akergirls from behind as they walk into the booth. Slow. Sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDING STUDIO MIXING BOOTH
dialogues.text: Only Keith is in here and there is a quiet moment where Dottie, Roxie and Cassie are alone. It’s the first honest god silence we’ve had in ten minutes. Dottie and Roxie embrace in the exact spot where Mari and Ali embraced at beginning of this act. They look through the glass at Bec She is actually focused, in real musician mode, tuning up getting ready. The Akergirls are connected and know what one another are thinking without saying it. They look like they sold thei souls to Satan. Keith points to the door; Cassie knocks i She opens it. Slowly.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDING STUDIO HALLWAY 25
dialogues.text: Cassie sticks her head into the hallway. She/we see Howar talking to Mari. Face puffy and wet with tears. She wipes them off both cheeks, looking cool. Zero in on this tough, hard woman undone by her friend. S left the studio a confident warrior, but it’s all surface  26 27 55. Dottie and Roxie look at her too and this tells them more about what they are dealing with than anything they’ve witnessed. It’s silent. Howard pushes past the girls, lea Mari to give one final look of warning.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You can’t be fully acquainted with Becky Something until you want her to fuck off. Remember that. She turns and walks away and we linger on the Akergirls, taking this omen to heart. One by one they file back in.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDING STUDIO MIXING BOOTH 26
dialogues.text: A moment of continued silence. Howard is, finally, uncharacteristically nervous. Focus on each Akergirl. Eac has a silent beat to convey how excitement turned to shoc nervousness to unease to fear. It’s hard for them. All look through the glass at Becky. We zero in on her, closer, slowly creeping as she finds her fingers lapsing from the guitar and snarls into the microphone, voice onl

dialogues.speaker: RECORDING STUDIO 27
dialogues.text: Half melodic. Half guttural. The messy but salvageable st you hear as the secret track at the end of a CD. Eyes closed, into the mic, she’s giving it her all and it passionate and if this was her first record instead of possibly her last, maybe it would be raw enough to impres but as it is, it’s just kind of sad. It’s the end of the she was playing at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: You look like you die, then apologize But fuck it I didn’t mean to see this through. And I’m back to the same shit I was Drowning in mud If I’m gonna be pulled down Then I’m taking you with And I’m back to the same shit. I was drowning in mud If I’m gonna be pulled down Then I’m taking you with. Back on the Akergirls as this plays out. We zero in on th letting the worried looks on their faces do all the talki END OF ACT TWO.  28 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAINY VHS HOME MOVIE FOOTAGE: Backstage at a club before show. Becky seems nervous, aloof and distant. She is quie standing away from Mari, Ali and her mother: ANIA. She ha the faintest trace of an accent. Ania is being friendly and hugging Mari and Ali.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Girls girls! I’m so proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: My mom would never ever ever come to a show.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: I never missed a show, a concert, a school play. Tell them Becky.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Basically you’re our mom, too.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Okay mom. Ania goes to Becky and squeezes her face with love and jo

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Oooh my baby’s nervous! So nervous!

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Stop it mom! She pushes Ania a little.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: You're so amazing. I’m so proud. She laughs with Mari and Ali. But Becky’s not laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest club really full with the eager and anxious. A bird's eye, overhead shot shows how packed it is. Moving through the crowd, we zero in from above, on Danny pushin through the crowd to the backstage door. He is waved thro by a bouncer. The place glows red like Hell, which is what it feels lik  29 30 57.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Have you seen Becky? Has she checked in? To everyone and no one, busy bodies in the corridor. Peop shake heads. He is agitated. This has gone on for a while playing the waiting game and when you play the waiting ga with Becky, you lose. ROCK CLUB, BECKY’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS 30 Danny’s feeling of relief is denied when he finds only An

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: How’s my grandbaby?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She’s home with Tiffany.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: You are great to that child.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: You did, when Rebecca left. Poor Daniel. Drawn into the family saga.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Time for a new family. Life goes on.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Hopefully, it does. A pregnant pause. Contemplating: what if it doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She’s not here. Everybody’s looking.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: What happened to my baby Rebecca. Did I do something that wrong? Oh Daniel. All we've put up with. For what?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: For love.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Ah. Yes. For love.  58. A quiet beat and then a knock on the door. This sequence a really rotten energy building, noise and motion growing more extreme. Things in the background, distance, hallway bump, fall and clatter. We’re heading toward motion sick territory. The crowd sounds and venue noise and neon ligh make this all feel pretty agitating. It’s just some RANDOM ROADIE who knocks.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM ROADIE
dialogues.text: She in here? Daniel and Ania shake heads. Roadie checks watch. Exhibit stress. RANDOM ROADIE (CONT’D) We're forty minutes behind. Venue’s lights out at midnight.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Don’t set your watch to Becky time. Roadie exits. Another moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: What are we doing here? She won't perform.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She has to.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Has to? Why?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Because I have a bad feeling that this is it for Becky.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Opening a small venue with proteges? She’s sold out arenas. Why do you fall for it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She cut the head off our life together. Swiftly and with no mercy. Apparently I’1ll never come to terms with that. He picks up some forms.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s way beyond what we agreed on for Tama. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've been trying to get her and these in the same room for three months.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Her lawyer quit. He called me.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Her plan is to ignore all the people suing her and hope they give up. Or die. Another knock on the now ajar door. It’s Ali. She’s had a pretty slick makeover since Act 2 and looks calm, measure and reasonable. She scans the room. No Becky.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Shoulda known. She cheek kisses Danny and then goes to Ania for a hug.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Alexandra, dear.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: We fell for it didn’t we.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Where do you find the faith?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s a curse. I'd kill to have none and never be waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Can't believe I got talked into this.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She needs you.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Every bully needs a weak punching bag to swing back for one more smack. Ali goes to the mirror. Applies more lip gloss to her alr extreme and ready-to-go show look. She looks awesome with pink eye shadow and glitter and feathery hair.

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who gives a shit about the players, right? They’re just here for Becky. What do I do? Quit and be nobody? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t belong in this world. I used to play church basements. I was happy there. I never wanted shows as big as this. Poor Ali van der Wolff. Plucked from the underground. A footnote in the defining oral history of the era. Silence falls after Ali’s speech, delivered to the mirror

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We all rely on her for something.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: We rely on Miss Something for something. Fame, work, money, love support. Opportunity. The golden goose sprays golden piss in our faces.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: She’s supported me for many years.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Me too. What a wretched feeling. As you know.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: I envy envy envy that optimism. What’s she ever done for you?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She gave me our daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: She drop kicked Tama to your doorstep from a speeding tour bus. Don’t confuse that with sainthood.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s not that simple. She wasn’t ready.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Oh Danny boy. I wanna believe you. You see our list? Nobody. Not a soul could be bothered. Such is the end of the saga of Something She. Ignominious. Fitting. So let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: I'm going to go talk to security.  61. Burst through the door: The Akergirls. You can tell in tw seconds that tonight is their night because they are perfectly styled in the coolest, most influential way a r band of girls in their early 20s. You see on their faces, though: the Becky panic. Because is a big show for them and the favor of letting Becky ope has already blown up in their young faces.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: She ain’t here.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Fuck fuck I fucking knew it.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: She’1l show.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Just don’t fucking talk to me okay?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That’s the spirit.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Dirtbag Danny! It’s really you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Just Danny.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: I taped your show religiously every night.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No shit? I don’t even have copies of the early years. You got some special stuff there.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: (interjecting) Anyway its just, this is like a big fuckin’ deal for us and all.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Always is. Nasty looks. Dottie won’t look at Roxie. They’ve split, a it’s created awkwardness between the whole band. They nev speak, make eye contact, or get close. It’s tense.

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t mind my trivializing your professional dilemma. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been in your shoes more times than I can count.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Give us a success ratio. Anything. I’m dying here. This is not okay. It’s not okay! Like, there are rules, right? Like we’ve gotta stick to the plan and the plan is written in ink, right?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: She'll be here. Might be any second... Pause. All look at door. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Might be in two hours. Its real cool and all what you’re doing for Becky. And me, I guess. Beck’s not used to not headlining. She forgets that nobody waits for the opener.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: We figured with all the people here for us--

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Because there’s industry in the room Becky would take this ten percent more seriously? Tried that one. If she didn’t know about all that, maybe she'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: What do we do.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Vocal warm up? I dunno what your pre show is. You wanna jam?

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: This is beyond me. Find me when the nightmare’s over. Dottie storms out, shooting daggers at mostly Roxie.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: She’s under a lotta pressure. We all are.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: And shit's wobbly with us right now. There’s heartbreak afoot.  63.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Wiser folks tried and failed. But hey I signed the contracts for today so if she don’t show you can sue her too. I think that’1ll be a baker’s dozen.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: (to Danny and Ania) Sorry. I’m Roxie. That was Dottie and this is Cassie.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Thank you for giving her this chance. She doesn’t make it easy.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: She'd do it for us. Already did, actually.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How'd you repay her? By fucking it all up? Silence. Knowing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She'll be here. The pattern is: disappear, leave you hanging, make you miserable and come back when she’s out of options. Ania takes Danny’s response in. She chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: My mom wouldn't step foot in a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: I’m not here to watch Becky inflict pain on others. There’s been enough of that to last lifetimes. I’m here because she needs me. Another silence. The energy in this room is tense and the keep being sounds in the hallway that make people jump, thinking it’s Becky. Howard enters.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Nada.  64.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Well this is great. That’s it. I’m done. It’s over. She’s cost me a house. Half my company. Can you accuse me of not trying hard enough? Did I not present opportunity after opportunity? And this is how it ends. (sees Ania) Forgive me, Ania. Lovely to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: I know it, you know it. Howard checks his watch. Looks at Cassie and Roxie.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Does it even matter how much longer we wait?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: We were supposed to start five minutes ago so as of now, we’re going on hour two of a sold out crowd waiting for something to happen.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I’m deeply sorry. If I’d known--- Cassie and Roxie shake their heads. You can hear it. Building outside this room. The tremble noise, anticipation growing louder. (BACK TO THE OVERHEAD SHOT OF THE CROWD. IT’S READY TO PO Howard and co. listen like it’s a Godzilla attack. Eyes w open, alarmed for how much longer they can survive in her

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give her ten more minutes. No. Five. Then it’s over. (to Ali) I’m sorry. You know nobody wants this night to go off more than me.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Wanna flip for it? I don’t suppose there’s any benefit in an Ali van der Wolff acoustic solo set.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: At this point any one on stage but Becky will make matters worse.  31 65.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Figured as much.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: So wise, are you. Ali puts her hands together and bows to them.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what now? Just then, they hear it. The crowd is going wild over something. Something is happening. (pun intended). (OVERHEAD SHOT OF VENUE: EVERYBODY IS ERUPTING. IT’S

dialogues.speaker: HAPPENING.
dialogues.text: The following utterance is of both relief and inevitabili

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: She’s here.

dialogues.speaker: ROCK CLUB CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Roxie, Cassie, Danny, Howard, Ania and Ali exit the dress room. Procession down the hall, one after the other, closer to stage. The further they walk, the more things change. The energy is stepping up a notch. There’s cheering, yell chanting coming through the walls and the looks on our character's faces are equal parts fear and curiosity. The ph balance of the building shifts, the temperature dr Our group gathers for the oncoming storm and focus shifts Ania, speaking to nobody, sadness and worry in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: I wanted the best for my baby girl. Music lessons. Rides to concerts. She played guitar in our church. In like a tornado comes Becky and if she knows she’s two hours late, she shows no sign. Her appearance backstage f out the cheers and applause as the exits the venue. A corridor where each open door offers a different sliver high contrast, neon light. Becky is riding high as she wa towards her throng of dependents chanting and clapping.  66.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Dem bones dem bones dem dry bones Dem bones dem bones dem dry bones Dem bones dem bones gonna walk around Dem bones dem bones gonna walk around Now hear the word of the lord Disconnecting dem bones, dem dry bones... She has an entourage in tow: Ya-Ema, looking dark and controlling and a documentary camera/boom mic crew of two Sad looking, down and out but they create some sense of heightened attention to what is otherwise not important. Becky wears an open leather jacket with just a pink bra underneath and the words ‘OLD SCRATCH’ scrawled on her to Her hair is huge, very 80s metal. Her makeup is theatrica Because of the video camera, Becky plays everything up to Nth degree in an effort to put on a good performance. It’ insufferable. She talks to the video camera, via to other people who are not listening. Rather than saying hello to mother, she is on lap three already.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ding dong the bitch is back. Who missed me show of hands? Howard pounces.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Two. Hours!

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Two. Minutes. To midniiiight! (Iron Maiden song) You're actually suing me, right? Or was that somebody else. I’1ll see you in court. Your honor. Is it a crime in this country to prefer the witching hour? I was born with an internal clock. The doctor left it inside me ha haaaa!! I call to the stand my mother, Mrs. Ania Adamczyk nee Smolinska. Mrs. Adamczyk, do you swear solemnly that your daughter was born with a rare neurological condition which renders the passage of time an enforced illusion of the external world? (as herself) Judge, please. I just can’t seem to get goin’ until later at night. You think I want to be late? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s people deserve a show and you have no idea the hell I’ve been through because I’m wishing there is any way on earth I could get going but just knowing I’m not going to make it. Promise me momma. When I die, have the coffin arrive half an hour late and written on the side in gold letters are the words ‘sorry for the delay.’ Ha HA! Oof. A terrible silence because, due to everything about Becky, the idea of her dying before her mother feels so r and perhaps inevitable. Everyone has been swept back away from the stage into the dressing room again. ROCK CLUB, BECKY’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS 32 It’s jam packed. Insanity, people moving everywhere to av bumping into others. Ya-Ema has dropped to his knees and wraps Becky’s ankles and places crystals from a bag on ea of her legs and feet and is lighting little sticks by her feet in some odd purification ritual. It’s pretty nutso looking and Becky’s camera gets it all, including an increasingly despondent Danny and Ania.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: (tears in her eyes) Rebecca. My sweet Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Mommmmmm, you're embarrassing me in front of my friends. I told you to wait in the car. They’re making a movie and I want them to see the real me so ix-nay on the ebecca-Ray.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: How can you inflict such pain? Becky looks at Ania and for a moment, the clouds of her m clear and her eyes change and if it’s remotely clear to anybody what she is thinking, they don’t let on.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ stop it with the dramatics, mom! I haven't seen you in months and you lay this down? Danny and Becky study one another, a major look passing. Becky looks at Ania, whose hands now reveal an envelope f her pocket.  68.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Don’t be ungrateful. Tell me you know I was always there.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: You get a pass. You did your time in the trenches but you were alone. Don’t you remember how alone you always were? You remember how you were always always alone.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: Your father wanted me to give you this letter.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Great throw it in the trash! Where was he fifteen years ago when I was nobody but his daughter? Becky grabs the envelope and tosses it.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: We should go.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: How’s married life, Dirtbag? Give my best to Tiffany.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: This is none of our business.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Stay babes. Your loyalty will be rewarded. That’s how it works. Isn't that right, Ali? She pronounces it like Muhammad “Ali.” Ah-lee.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Funny, I didn’t know you saw me here.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Kid, your energy is so foul I could see you in the dark. Ania losing her composure. She came in here, brave and confident, but as usual, Becky is breaking her. She stand Danny silently asking for and receiving support from him.

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Danny) Oh Daniel. Why?  69. Ya-Ema, clearing Becky’s aura, gives Ali a mean glance. S ignores it, and Becky’s rude remark. Taking the high road

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: You ready to rock?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I was born ready. Doesn’t everybody know that by now? You think I need to warm up like some mere mortal? I don’t think so, Tim. Would I have stepped foot in this joint if I wasn’t ready for a double-V victory and if that means a great show two hours later than a crummy one people can thank me later alligator. (to Roxie/Cassie) Children, join me in the sacred circle of spiritual cleanse. Where’s the third member of your coven? (screaming) DOTTIE 0.Z. you your butt in here this instant you are guh-rounded! (to Ania/Danny) How’m I doing mom? Mother of the year over here, ya dig! Ania steps away from Becky, unwilling to play this game. Dottie runs in, frantic. Surveys Becky, seated with wraps crystals, smoke around her, everybody else buzzing nervou around, Danny and Ania moving away, Cassie and Roxie in shock. The video camera whips to get her entrance.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Finally.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Girls, gather round. Join the circle of energy. Anybody who does not to be here you can leave or avert your gaze. (to video camera) Not you. Becky closes her eyes. Ali and the Akergirls do the same.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dear goddess of creativity and positivity, Becky here. How’s it going? I’m speaking to you tonight not only on behalf of myself but also my little sisters Dottie 0.Z., Cassie Crassy and Roxie Rotten. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a big night for them so let’s take care of Akergirls. They’re swell kids and deserve the best. She pauses. The energy shifts and people sense something. leans in, alarmed, like Becky is about to drift away. Bec breathing changes and it’s really weird.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As for me. Lady, if you’re listening still, I need this. I need this bad. This is it for ol’ Beckster. I’m gonna need your help here because the last train is leaving the station and if I’m not on it when the whistle blows, that’s it for me. Lights out. Last call. Soup’s cold. Ice cream’s melting. Beer’s warm. Yuck. Let’s rally, one more time, then you can take that soul I promised you. Danny shuffles, alarmed, when she says this. Becky stops prayer. Everybody is silent. The doubt of Howard and Ali about her not grasping the importance of tonight is gone. Maybe Becky was late because she actually wants to make t perfect. Maybe she is all clear headed and aware of herse finally. Becky looks right at the video camera.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Joan of Arc she ain’t. Flames or not. Go home. We’ll talk tomorrow. Both look at the bathroom door. There’s an unspoken thing here but Ali’s going to speak it. She holds back tears.

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: ANIA

This is all about the people ar Becky and how she affects them. We stay on the Akergirls it’s clear, following Act 2, that they are through the looking glass with Becky. Now they want to tell her to fu off. There’s silent sadness among the Akergirls. They watch Al and Ania walk to Becky’s bathroom and they exit, giving t privacy. A quiet moment in a story light on them.

dialogues.text: Follow the Akergirls to their dressing room. More orderly less intense than the one we just left. Silent. They look their mirrors, grab a water, a cigarette. They start ligh candles around a small table on the floor. Finally:

The girls take hands and close their eyes, ready to lapse into a mystical seance which is their tradition before sh ROCK CLUB, BECKY’S DRESSING ROOM - THAT SAME MOMENT 34 Ali and Ania lean on the door. We are close to Ali, close enough to see the tears and anxiety on her face. Talking wall. No better metaphor for dealing with Becky.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: I didn’t want it to be like this. Why did you make it have to be like this? I blame you, Beck. You found me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You invited me. I never wanted any of it. I only wanted to rock with you and Mari. Not all this. The door opens. Becky is glassy eyed, doped up. She looks like a tranquilized animal. In a way, she is. She looks a Ania, holding the letter she brought.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: You weak stupid wimp. After everything he has put us through. I uses to look up to you. Ania is gutted. She is in agony, as usual, because of Bec

dialogues.speaker: ANIA
dialogues.text: I always hoped you were better than this. Deep down I knew you weren’t. You're more like your father than you'll ever know. Ania takes the letter and grabs Becky’s hand, shoving it The forcefulness of Ania’s negativity momentarily stuns B silent, static, stunned. (So this is where she gets it... Ania exits quickly as the letter falls to the floor. Ali picks the letter up but Becky grabs at it and they become attached. Becky has slipped into a trance.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Destroy it!! They struggle for control of the paper as it tears in the hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALI

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Negative forces! I cast you out! Be gone from here and wipe this room of evil. Let in the light and forsake the darkness. They are rolling on the ground and Becky doesn’t let go. grabs for stuff, lamps and tapestries and furniture and around them the entire room crumbles and collapses inward Ema watches silently and the video camera gets it all.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: You're hurting me-- Becky has a hand on Ali’s throat as well as her forehead. is out of her mind hallucinating.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Demon, speak not to me. To hear your words is to open myself to your trickery. She puts her hand over Ali’s mouth and Ali continues to struggle to protect herself.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Beckpthhhh sttttppp Becky takes a glass bottle, breaks it and brandishes with free hand. We go close to see the abject terror and uncertainty in Ali's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I've fought you in eleven other lives and in eleven other lives you've destroyed me. I’ve seen the faces you’ve used and my demise at your hands across the centuries. Now at last I’ve looked across time and I see how to defeat those who will see me destroyed! Becky is scratching herself and Ali with the glass. Red m and pricks of blood are forming. Ali tries to yell for he but she is out of breath. It’s not loud enough and she ma direct eye contact with Ya-Ema who stands with folded han and will not move a finger to help and the camera crew, filming and not helping.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)

Ali somehow gets free, knocks Becky in the face. Bloody n Her weapon falls and the blood runs down her exposed ches under the jacket. Ali stumbles to the door, heaves at it, tears it open and screams as loud as she can.

A crazed look on her face like ‘can’t you take joke’ but because her nose is bloody and she has OLD SCRA written on her sweaty, bloody torso and all the rest, she looks truly dangerous. The two old friends stare at one another across the trash room, bloody, out of breath, frenzied. Becky’s stupid ins smile is infuriating.

dialogues.text: And she laughs for a few seconds before losing her balanc and steading herself on a chair just as Howard rushes in a big security guard. They are prepared for an OD so when they rush in are surprised to see Becky has the upper han survey the mess and injuries and Ali looks the most afrai Security goes to Becky to restrain her and even though he 6’'4” and 300 pounds she puts up a hell of a fight. She c and kicks and is lifted off the ground but lands a few bl

dialogues.text: Miss, shut your mouth and stop attacking me please.

Becky bites the security guard and is able to get free. S grabs the glass bottle again and points it at him. The gu lunges forward and she slices his arm. It’s bleeding and kicks her, pretty hard, to get her to drop the weapon and finally pins her against a wall and puts handcuffs on her Like a rabid dog, Becky barks and tries to bite people bu never stops looking happy, grinning, smiling because some it hasn't sunk in yet that this isn’t a game. She barks a snarls right at the video camera lens. Off to the side, Ali is regaining herself and cleaning wo and standing in the doorway, which we haven’t seen until are the Akergirls, watching Becky bite and snarl. The documentary crew is getting it all. Becky, fallen to floor, handcuffed, bleeding, looks up at her audience wit delight and joy. There’s a physical fight in her body bec the adrenaline is wearing off and it’s fighting the drugs she is starting to get wobbly.

dialogues.text: (to Ali) Can you...anything?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey! Sorry I messed up your pretty face. Nobody is listening. Becky stands to run, chase after Ali

The camera crew is at the foot of the stage, getting it a Security climbs to the stage. Becky slips away from him a grabs the mic.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been back through the ages of earth and I’ve witnessed centuries of conflict. I regressed to the moment of conception and watched myself being born. That's why I’m leaving now. When I needed it, nobody ever put a hand on my back and told me it was gonna be alright dude. It’s the little things. Security senses she isn’t a threat but is still holding h or at least blocking her from going anywhere and she’s stumbling, backed up against the speakers with nowhere to Faint response. People are alarmed. Becky is fading. She takes a guitar and tries to play but it’s impossible her hands cuffed and she spins the guitar, falls hard off stage into the equipment area and people rush to her, hud around and she’s clutching the guitar which broke her fal Feedback starts to wail. Becky isn’t laughing or talking. She looks up at people, eyes like a dying animal and she looks like someone wakin from amnesia and finally understanding where she is. A li girl, lost and afraid. She reacts with shaky fear. Feedback is still wailing and the video camera is in her and flash photos are going off and security is trying to her up but she’s like a protestor, heavy and inert. He lifts Becky, guitar and all. She’s dead weight as she carried through the venue to the exit, toward a police ca whose sirens we can already hear and whose red/blue flash lights get brighter the further he walks. The look on her face is fear and panic. Like she just woke up here and doesn’t know what is happening. Her energy dangerously al Feedback is still wailing, fading away from the stage. Be looks at the faces of the Akergirls as she passes. They a next to Howard and Becky is all bloody and weak.

With that, she stares, eyes wide open as if trying to pro a world, a realm of reality she doesn’t comprehend and is carried in the arms of security out the door into the waiting, wailing bright lights of oblivion.  38 79. People look around, back at the stage. They see The Akerg and Howard off to the side. There is still feedback which Dottie puts a stop to as Howard draws the club’s little curtain down, concealing them from view. END OF ACT THREE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAINY VHS HOME MOVIE FOOTAGE: Backyard of Becky’s new ho It’s nice and has a pool. Becky, in a pool chair, holds a week old Tama. She is smoking a cigarette and dozing.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanna stay home with my baby. No tour. No record. I like it here. Danny shows up, around the corner. He looks confused abou why a camera is there. Becky doesn’t look up at him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh. I see. You ready for me to take her home?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Take her. Take her. I’m so tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft, breeze blown curtains. A big, empty, isolated, some dilapidated house with windows open. Glowing, soft light everywhere and this looks like a cartoon idea of heaven, contrasting with the red hell we just left behind of Act Becky is dwarfed by the huge space. Paint is chipped and peeling, floorboards warped and scuffed. She bought a fix upper and will never fix it up. This is going to be slow, static, locked off. (So even th this is half the page length of other acts, it’1ll be rou the same amount of time.) The camera never moves and seldom cuts. Becky’s life is immobile now. She’s in a thin, soft sweater over a tatter old Evergreen College shirt. Beyond natural. No makeup. S clean hair. The mask of theatricality is no more. Looking her, you'd almost think she’d been lobotomized. Becky Something doesn’t live here. Just Rebecca Adamczyk. The tea kettle boils and whistles in the kitchen.  39 40 80.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY HOUSE, KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Becky oozes out of a stupor and floats like a ghost to th kitchen. It has signs of detox: dozens of lemons, ginger, jugs of expensive water. This is all slow: feel time pass Becky pours the water and marks a tally on what is obviou a sobriety calendar: it’s approaching a full year. She borders on catatonic and the silence here at this poi in our story is extreme and shocking as anything. We’ve h nearly two minutes of it which is one minute fifty second more than we ever heard so far. It’s haunting and you sho think that Becky is dead, this is the afterlife, and this story is going someplace unexpected. From where her tea steeps, Becky sees a car pull up. She turns away and prepares to have to see somebody.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY HOUSE, LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Walking through a room with a bunch of South American religious artifacts, crystals, new age stuff and a pin ba machine, Becky sits and waits for the knock on the door. Danny enters with Tama. He looks pretty sharp, hair a bit cleaner, clothes more sophisticated. Tama is now four and half. She doesn’t seem comfortable here, since the place so empty and not homey. The tea is in her hand and the silence is broken by the t timer ringing. She removes the tea basket and, though it dripping, puts it on a table with no dish. Becky and Tama look at each other for a moment. Becky’s s face finally changes into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: (horse voice, weird sounding) Baby.

dialogues.text: Mommy . They hug. Becky swallows her tragedy because the pain of confronting the reality of how bad she fucked up kills he

dialogues.speaker: TAMA
dialogues.text: I missed momma.  4l 81. Becky is dying inside. This is agony.

dialogues.text: Yeah okay! There is already a Tama stool by the machine for her mont visits. She begins to play. The game noises are soft and fading as Becky and Danny walk to another big, sparse roo COUNTRY HOUSE, MUSIC ROOM - CONTINUOUS 4l This one is full of instruments and simple, vintage recor gear to prove that Becky is still active. Like the other rooms, it has big open windows and feels quiet and soft a in addition to pinball, you hear birds and bugs and wind. Becky cannot make eye contact with Danny, ashamed and ful self loathing. But she isn’t fully broken. Always, embers danger are within her, and the threat is there. You see it on Danny’s face. He isn’t sure she can stay so forever, but is impressed as this is the longest she has gone. This year came after a relapse or two. It’s about sixteen months since Act 3. Becky, in recovering addict mode, can feel people looking cracks when they are with her. It feels awful. She holds tea in both hands, like it will shield her.

dialogues.text: You look good.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Bullshitter. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: I know. That’s really great. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: She misses me?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t really know you. Immediately, this makes Becky choke up, but no tears. She too isolated from her emotions for tears.

dialogues.text: I had this dream. We were brothers in a past life and we were Native American. You killed all the children in our tribe. And that’s why I was so horrible to you in this life. Danny cannot fathom a response to this. He reaches into a and hands her legal looking documents.

And just for this moment, it’s too bad that Becky has an audience of one because what she is about to deliver is t most achingly beautiful, soul-deep performance of maybe h entire life. And if she were to be playing this for an audience of 10,000, there wouldn't be a dry eye in the ho It's deep, tender, emotional. From a place deep within herself where the pure love lives. The love so deep it wa protected from all the drugs, pain and misery she caused herself and others. It’s closer to a hymn, filling up a church with tones of reverie and spiritual meaning and th reason she can muster all that is because it’s all for Ta One of the best songs ever written: HEAVEN by Bryan Adams

For something to arrive. For love to come along. Now our dreams are coming true. Through the good times and the bad. Yeah I’ll be standing there by you. And baby you’re all that I want. When you’re lying here in my arms. I’m finding it hard to believe. We’re in heaven. And love is all that I need. And I found it there in your heart. It wasn’t too hard to see. We’re in heaven. dialogues.text: (swallowing a lump) Hey B. The room opens up when Becky takes Tama in her lap and tu

dialogues.text: Aunt Mari did you hear? Mom sang a song just for me.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Yeah. I heard.

dialogues.speaker: TAMA
dialogues.text: You should sing for me too sometime.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: I will. Promise. Danny is moved. This represents a total change in Becky.

dialogues.speaker: MARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Been playing anything else?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Uh huh. You wanna hear?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Yeah. I do.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sweetie, why don’t you come fix lunch with daddy?

dialogues.speaker: TAMA
dialogues.text: Mom said she’d make me a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Dad can get this one. I’1l make the next one.  88.

dialogues.speaker: TAMA
dialogues.text: Okay momma but you have to make the next one. Tama kisses Becky and runs to Danny, who swoops her up. H looks at Becky and Mari, knowing they should be alone. He exits. Mari and Becky feel it out. They haven’t seen one another coming up on three years.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: She’s so beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I lost so much time with her.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: She’s lucky to have you back.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I had a vision of you holding her at my funeral. I saw you and Danny, holding her hands and I was so happy that you were godmother. I’ve seen my death a dozen times in a dozen different ways. In every vision I’m surrounded by people. I never die alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You’re alone now. You should leave this place.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: There’s an ache in my bones. Mari takes a minute. This is a crushing thing to respond She sits down near the piano. Puts the present she has be holding down. Becky looks at it, devoid of curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: It’s from Howard.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Thanks Howard. How’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Well, actually. The Akergirls hit big. Their new stuff isn’t my cup of tea but they’ve done well for him. He'd love to see you. Becky squirms. Wants to change the subject.  89.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Thank you for taking my call. Back then. You didn’t have to.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: I was always the bigger person.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Ali didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You never tried to stab me. Except in the back. Which you did.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: How’s she been?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Good. She just put out an album with her husband. It’s kinda great.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Husband?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Roy. They’re amazing together.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I should get a copy.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Mine’s out in the car.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I’1l buy my own.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: I don’t think she’s mad at you anymore. I don’t think I’m mad at you anymore either. You were horrible. But it never made me not love you. Becky nods. Insulted, but Mari had to get it out.

dialogues.speaker: MARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lauren’s seven months pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Danny told me. That’s rad. I’m happy for you. (pause) You'll be a really good mom. Silence. This is getting harder, not easier.  90.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You ever jam?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Alone. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You wanna? Nobody has offered Becky this much of an inch of opportun in years. It’s major for her and you see it in her eyes. tries to downplay how much it means to be given a shot.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Sure. You wanna hear some stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: (equally downplaying) Sure. For a moment, it’s almost old times. Sisterhood and creat energy between them. Becky goes to the reel to reel she h been using to record demos in exile. It plays out slowly. Becky moving, having finished her te the precision of somebody whose brain isn’t quite right. cues up the device and hesitates before pressing play. Lo over her shoulder and off in the distance sees Tama lurki in a far off door frame holding a triangle PB&J sandwich half. Danny is behind her, maintaining Becky and Mari’s distance and space. Becky looks back to Mari, slumps down, on the floor, surrounded by instruments and gear.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Don’t like, tell people anything about what you hear.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t---

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Just...if anybody asks. Does anybody ask?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: (pause) Not as much as they used to.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Only...be kind, alright?  91. Becky never expressed any sensitivity or need for approva not once in their entire career together so Mari knows it actually a different person, draped in soft fabric hangin off her lithe, weakened frame. The ghost of Becky future.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Just between us. Becky presses play and sits with her back to Mari: she ca hear her own recording while playing and look her in the Two women, facing forward, Becky holding her guitar, Mari staring at Becky’s back. The song starts. It’s simple, raw, rough, emotional, and pure. Becky accompanies the recording, strumming and also singing live. The record is a 4-track, simple stuff. It’s short and is, as the critics would say, Classic Becky. (This song is called ‘Expected to Grow’ and was written b Alicia Bognanno/aka Bully)

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Slipping out I’ve caused you pain I shake at the thought of it Anyone could shift the blame But I’m the root the cause of it I don’t think I’ve learned Anything since you Taking ten steps back Polarize the view And how can I be expected to grow If I’m stuck living in what I Already know and I don’t wanna quit I just wanna be in control of it I don’t wanna quit I just wanna be in control of it What I recall Is cold and mean I owe good health and time to you But I get stuck To the wrong things And only space shows me the truth I have not learned I have learned nothing since you Taking ten steps back Polarize the truth It’s clear to Mari that this is exactly what they were tr to make in Act 2, a return to form that is also a leap forward. Somehow, Becky exorcised the demons and created  92.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Beck it’s incredible.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Just a little thing. Mari looks and see stacks of recordings around the machin Becky has enough for a double album and four bootlegs her An epic amount of music. She sees Mari looking.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s mostly junk.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You know I’d follow you anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Still?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: That's my bad habit. Yours is, well, everything. Mine is coming back and coming back for more.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I fucked you over a hundred times.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Hundred and one.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I can let people hear this. I think it’s just too, too, just too much.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Yeah okay.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I don’t deserve another chance.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You're gonna get it whether you want to or not. You’re lucky I’ma masochist who, still, just wants to get dressed up, feel pretty and play new music plus the hits. They still love you.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: They always loved me. It’s not loving them back that got me here.  93.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: So what? You stay here and die in this house?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I always thought I’d die on stage. There’s nothing here than can hurt me. I have to stay here, or else...

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: It’s not over until you get what's yours.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Somehow I’ve cheated it. It’s very real. It wasn’t that time, so maybe it’ll be next time. So there can’t ever be a next time.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Becky that’s insane.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: No. It isn’t. Ya-Ema once told me that Tama would be my downfall. I thought he meant she would bring my downfall. It wasn’t until later that I realized he meant my love for her is my true weakness.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: I don’t buy any of that. And you shouldn’t still talk about him. He’s a fraud. He took advantage of you and lots of others and he’s in jail now for it.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: He understood me.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Okay whatever. You don’t need him and you never did. You never knew how to rely on others. That’s your weakness. People are waiting to see who Becky Something really is.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Who is she? Mari smiles and makes an ‘I don’t know’ shrug.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: She’s a woman.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: She’s a user.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: She’s a mother.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: She’s a deadbeat.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: A person.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: A persona.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: You're healthy.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Recovering.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Okay then. Who was Becky Something?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: A way to hide from Rebecca Adamczyk.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Who was she?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I dunno. Nobody’s seen her since I was sixteen. Tama comes in, interrupting. Leaps at Becky.

dialogues.speaker: TAMA
dialogues.text: Momma I’m bored.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I know sweetheart. Mommy’s just catching up with Aunt Mari.

dialogues.speaker: TAMA
dialogues.text: Can we go outside to play?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let’s go outside. They stand up and slowly get together. Mari knows this conversation is over but the seed has been planted. Offer on the table.  42 43 95. Danny joins from the kitchen as they walk to the door whi leads to the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the first time in this story we have been outside it’s shocking. Vampiric. Becky shrinks a little and adjus her eyes, breaths fresh air, reacts to nature. We’ve neve seen her outdoors, ever. Tama runs off into the yard. Danny puts his hand on Becky’s shoulder as they watch Tam lovingly and he gives her a small look of acceptance and reassurance and that’s all she ever wanted. Becky steps away from it and into the light and walks off porch into the yard and follows Tama into a thicket of tr and lets the sun light and wind and all the rest wash ove her and her clothes are flowing and she looks like a ghos a movie whose spirit is finally let go and dissolves or evaporates into the air. It has that eerie vibe about it. END OF ACT FOUR. INTERLUDE #5 (No context) GRAINY VHS HOME MOVIE FOOTAGE: Becky, Mari and Ali are collapsed in delirious laughter on the floor in front of paper photo shoot backdrop. This is the photo shoot for t Spin cover from Interlude 1. Their faces are turning red, they are gasping for air as laugh: just them together, physically, emotionally, havin fun and loving being in a band. The Best of Times.

dialogues.speaker: ACT FIVE
dialogues.text: INT. THE VENUE, BECKY’S DRESSING ROOM 43 The same venue from Act One. Same camera patterns with lighting that starts off different, a transition from the balanced, calming hues of Act 4 back to the familiar neon buzz of Act One. This is the end of a full circle. Becky looks different: classy and kind of amazing. She ha stylist now and wears designer-ish clothes. Her hair is c and her makeup is mature and appropriate without being a departure from her true style. Becky is alone, bouncing about like a pinball. We feel th anxiety and confusion of this experience.  96. She is about to re-enter the public eye and this is the f moment to herself before the final moments of Becky’s sto Everything here, every image, gesture, word and suggestio point towards a definitive conclusion. It’s looming. Stay with her as she appreciates the quiet but see also h wrecked with anxiety she is. It feels like she may be abo to snap. You faintly hear a concert happening already. Knock on the door. Becky breaths deep. It’s all now or ne

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ali and Mari come in. Obviously they’ve been practicing a stuff so this isn’t the reunion but it’s a reunion of the public personas and that feels substantial. The women circle one another, silent, smiling, looking at their stage outfits.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: So bitchin’, babe.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Thank you. (she curtseys) Mari is happy and not hiding it; she brought this togethe

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Nope. It feels good. Becky looks to Ali for backup.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: It’s pretty alright. Another knock. It’s a PHOTOGRAPHER with the event. Howard with him and beams with pride at seeing the gang back together. He has on a suit and tie. He has flowers for Be He kisses them all on the cheeks and hands. Hands her the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You all look incredible. Thank you. Really, thanks for doing this.  97.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Christ Goodman, we’re not Lady Lazarus the damn Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: It’s my night. You tried hard as you could to torpedo my business but somehow the company has survived for twenty years so let me throw a living wake.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Anybody mind if we get a few quick photos?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Ahhhh, so that’s why you’re here.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You don’t think I actually wanted to see any of you? They all push back against a wall and pose, Howard and Be in the middle. Smiles all around. Show Mari, Ali and Beck faces as the flashes go off. Holding smiles. Faking it. L King Kong having his photo taken. Feel the pressure on Be as the press and the publicity machine begins to consume He exits.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: That’s it. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: See you out there?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (to Becky) It means a lot to me that you’re here. I mean it. I’m nearly speechless.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Not nearly enough ya big sap. Get outta here. Tonight’s not about me. Howard exits and pauses at the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Why couldn’t you be this smart ten years ago?  98.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I never thought I’d live this long and wanted to avoid it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: See you ladies on stage.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Hey. Thanks for sticking by me.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: There was never a question. Mari blows a kiss and Ali waves with both hands. You can the current band finish, yell ‘THANK YOU AND THANK YOU HOWARD’ and applause and they exit the stage. Mari and Ali are noticing how jittery and on edge Becky i

dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Yeah’m. Yeah. Fine. It’s iffy and it’s odd being back. Do you hear the ghosts? The bones and chains rattling? Do you feel the spirits of the past?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: It's different. This space is the same but we’re different.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen it sober before.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: I told you. It sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the Akergirls and they just got off the stage so the are sweaty but very awesome looking. They too have mature styles, even though they are still like 26. Super chic, n longer rocker slobbish. Like Zelda in Act 1, they’ve foun the art crowd and have even done advertising campaigns. T sit in the front at some fashion shows now.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Oh fuck looky here. All hug, smiles, kisses.  99.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Shit you look ah-may-zing.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Still breathing.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: That must be it.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Look at this hair.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Alright alright you’re making me feel like a specimen.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: Our new record just came out.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: I know. It’s the best one yet.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Everybody says the one we made together is the best.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: That’s because they’re assholes who don’t want artists to change. I’m serious. It’s on repeat. I love it.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: What about you? Doing anything after this?

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ROXIE
dialogues.text: No, like in the futurrre, man. Something She look at one another....elephant in the room Becky averts her eyes.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MARI
dialogues.text: Abhhh. Um---

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Unknown. We’re here for Howard. Just trying to get through tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Yeah how crazy is this? Did you see Zelda's here? (looks at Becky) Shit, sorry. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: It’s fine. We've spoken. She heard what I had to say. Actually: she still around?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: BECKY
dialogues.text: Maybe this means something. Excuse me. Becky exits swiftly. The room is quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: It’s great to see you girls. I’m glad you're here for this. She looks at Roxie and Dottie, who are warm and affection

dialogues.speaker: DOTTIE
dialogues.text: Yeah man. Life goes on.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
